member.summary: Gets the time of impact between two moving objects.
member.param: The allowed penetration. A positive allowed penetration value makes sure that the objects have a measurable contact at the time of impact.
member.returns: The time of impact in the range [0, 1].

remarks.para: Both objects are moved from their current pose (time = 0) to the given target pose (time = 1). If they collide during this movement the first time of impact is returned. A time of impact of 1 can mean that the objects do not collide or they collide at their target positions.
The result is undefined if the objects are already in contact at their start poses.
Notes to Inheritors: The base implementation already computes the time of impact for convex shapes. For other shapes it returns 1. Optimized versions should be implemented in derived classes.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Collisions.Algorithms.HeightFieldAlgorithm
member.summary: Computes contact or closest-point information for vs. any other .

remarks.para: This algorithm will fail if it is called for collision objects with other shapes. This algorithm will call other algorithms to compute collision with parts of the height field.

The height field is treated as a collection of triangles. The algorithm gives the triangle a "thickness" so that collisions are detected, even if the colliding object is under the height field surface. This avoids tunneling problems.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Geometry.Collisions.Algorithms.HeightFieldAlgorithm.WeldingLimit
member.summary: This value determines when contact welding should be performed.

remarks.para: To avoid bad contact normals, a process called "welding" is performed when the contact normal deviates from the triangle normals. When the dot product of a contact normal and the related triangle normal is less than , the welding process checks and improves the contact.
The default value is 0.999.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Collisions.CollisionDomain
member.summary: A collision domain that manages collision objects.

remarks.para: The can be used for ad hoc collision queries between any two objects. The is designed to manage multiple collision objects at once and allows faster contact queries.

The method must be called in each frame (time step) to update the collision domain. computes all collisions between all objects inside the domain. The resulting contacts are stored in . The collision domain reuses collision data from the last frame. Additionally, if the property is set, the workload is distributed across multiple CPU cores. Therefore the collision computation is much faster in comparison to ad hoc queries (as in ).
A can only compute real contacts (geometric objects are touching or intersecting), but it does not calculate closest-point queries for separated objects. Use to calculate the closest-point queries.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Geometry.Collisions.CollisionDomain.EnableMultithreading
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether multithreading is enabled.
member.value: if multithreading is enabled; otherwise, . The default value is if the current system has more than one CPU cores.

remarks.para: When multithreading is enabled the collision domain will distribute the workload across multiple processors (CPU cores) to improve the performance.

Multithreading adds an additional overhead, therefore it should only be enabled if the current system has more than one CPU core and if the other cores are not fully utilized by the application. Multithreading should be disabled if the system has only one CPU core or if all other CPU cores are busy. In some cases it might be necessary to run a benchmark of the application and compare the performance with and without multithreading to decide whether multithreading should be enabled or not.

The collision domain internally uses the class for parallelization. is a static class that defines how many worker threads are created, how the workload is distributed among the worker threads and more. (See to find out more on how to configure parallelization.)

This method should only be used in special cases - whenever possible should be used instead. The collision detection caches a lot of information to improve performance. By updating only a single collision object the collision detection might remain in an inconsistent state. That is, the collision objects might have contact, but the contact information is missing.

Example 1 of an inconsistent state: was the first hit of a ray that stops at first hits (see ). Now is moved and does not touch the ray anymore. When is called in this situation, the collision detection might remain in an inconsistent state. When is called the contact information of is updated and the between the and the ray will be removed. Since the ray is now no longer blocked by the it might hit another object. However, the contact information of the ray is not updated.

Example 2 of an inconsistent state: Some collision objects have moved since the last call of . is moved into contact with one of the moved objects. Now for is called. The broad phase information of is updated. But - depending on the type of broad phase algorithm - the broad phase information of the other objects might not be updated. The collision detection uses the cached broad phase information from the previous . So the collision detection might not find all contacts for .
To sum up: Use this method carefully. Try to use instead. Call this method only if is the only object that has moved since the last call of .

member.summary: A basic collision filter supporting pairwise filtering and collision groups.

remarks.para: Per default, all collisions are enabled. Collisions can be disabled for pairs of s, for a pair of collision groups, or for a whole collision group. Collision groups are identified by an ID, stored in the (see ). Per default, the collision filter supports only collision group IDs in the range 0-31. This limit can be changed in the constructor (see ).

Two collision objects A and B will NOT collide if one of the following conditions is met:
Collisions for the collision group of A are disabled (see ).
Collisions for the collision group of B are disabled (see ).
Collisions between the collision group of A and the collision group of B are disabled (see ).
Collisions between collision object A and B are disabled (see ).

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Collisions.Contact
member.summary: Describes a contact (or the closest points) of two objects.

remarks.para: A is the result of a collision query. s are usually stored in a . A describes a single contact point (or closest-point pair), whereas a contains all contacts between two objects. (The involved objects are called "object A" and "object B".)
A includes 2 points: a point on object A (see or ) and a point on object B (see or ). The property is a point that lies halfway between those two points.

There are 4 types of contacts:
Touching Contact: Object A and object B are touching at the surface. The is 0. The points on object A and object B are identical. , , and are identical.
Penetrating Contact: Object A and object B are penetrating each other. The is greater than 0. , and are different and describe the points on object A and B that have maximum penetration. lies halfway between these two points.
Closest points (separated objects): Object A and object B are separated. They are not in contact. This can be the result of a closest-point query (see ). Normal contact queries such as or the contact queries performed inside a ignore separated objects!
The is negative. The absolute value of indicates the distance between the object A and object B. (The "penetration depth" is the inverse of "separation distance".) and are the closest points between the two objects. lies halfway between the closest points.
Closest-point query is a special type of collision query. At first this might look confusing: Why does a closest-point query return a ? The reason that contacts and closest points are represented by the same class is that the collision detection internally treats contacts and closest points the same way.
Ray Hit: Either object A or object B is a ray that hits the other object. The stores the distance from the ray origin to the contact position on the second object. The describes the surface normal at the contact position.
(Ray hits can easily be found by checking whether the property is set in a .)

member.summary: Gets or sets the penetration depth.

remarks.para: This is the distance which the two object have to move along the contact normal (see ) to be in a touching state (no penetration and no separation). For penetrating contacts this value is positive. For separated objects this value is negative. (The "penetration depth" is the inverse of the "separation distance".)

For ray-casting: If this value is positive, the ray hits the object and the is the distance from the origin of the ray origin to the contact point. If the value is negative the ray misses the object and the absolute value of the indicates the separation distance between the ray and the other object (closest points).

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Collisions.ICollisionFilter
member.summary: Represents a configurable collision filter supporting pairwise filtering and collision groups.

remarks.para: Per default, all collisions are enabled. Collisions can be disabled for pairs of s, for a pair of collision groups, or for a whole collision group. Collision groups are identified by an ID, stored in the (see ).

Two collision objects A and B will NOT collide if one of the following conditions is met:
Collisions for the collision group of A are disabled (see ).
Collisions for the collision group of B are disabled (see ).
Collisions between the collision group of A and the collision group of B are disabled (see ).
Collisions between collision object A and B are disabled (see ).

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Collisions.IContactFilter
member.summary: A filter which processes contacts in a contact set.
member.remarks:
Contact filters are called in the narrow phase (in s) to post-process the found contacts. Example usages of a contact filter:
Remove redundant contacts. Some applications, like rigid body physics, needs only a minimal set of contacts, e.g. only 4 contacts per .
Remove "bad" contacts, for example contacts where the normal direction points into an undesired direction.
Merge contacts. For some applications it is useful to keep only one contact which is the average of all other contacts.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Geometry.GeometryHelper.CreateConvexHull(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3F},System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a convex hull mesh for a set of points.
member.param: The vertex limit. Must be greater than 0. Common values are 32 or 64.
The skin width. Common values are 0.01 or 0.001.
member.returns: The mesh of the convex hull or if the point list is or empty.

remarks.para: The returned mesh describes the convex hull. All faces are convex polygons.

If the created convex hull has more vertices than , the hull will be simplified. The simplified hull is conservative, which means it contains all given and is less "tight" than the exact hull. It is possible that the simplified hull contains slightly more vertices than (e.g. it is possible that for a vertex limit of 32 a hull with 34 vertices is returned).
All planes of the convex hull are extruded by the . This can be used to increase or decrease the size of the convex hull.

member.remarks:
The outcode is a code that contains information of the point position relative to the box.
Bit 0 is set if the point is outside of the plane defined by the -x face of the box.
Bit 1 is set if the point is outside the +x plane.
Bit 2 is set if the point is outside the -y plane.
Bit 3 is set if the point is outside the +y plane.

If the outcode is 0, then the point is inside the box.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.IGeometricObject
member.summary: Defines an object that has a and a (position and orientation).

remarks.para: Classes that need to implement can derive from .

Important: An instance registers event handlers for the event of the contained . Therefore, a will have an indirect reference to the . This is no problem if the geometric object exclusively owns the shape. However, this could lead to problems ("life extension bugs" a.k.a. "memory leaks") when multiple geometric objects share the same shape: One geometric object is no longer used but it cannot be collected by the garbage collector because the shape still holds a reference to the object.

Therefore, when s are shared between multiple s: Always set the property to when the is no longer used. is a special immutable shape that never raises any events. Setting to ensures that the internal event handlers are unregistered and the object can be garbage-collected properly.
Cloning: Geometric objects are cloneable. The method creates a deep copy of the geometric object - except when documented otherwise (see description of implementing classes).

Notes to Inheritors: The support for cloning of geometric objects is built-in in DigitalRune Geometry because several applications built upon the library rely on the cloning mechanism. The DigitalRune Geometry library internally does not use the cloning mechanism. So, if you need to write your own type that implements and your own application does not require to clone geometric objects, you can simply omit the implementation of - just throw a .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Meshes.DcelMesh
member.summary: A mesh represented by a Doubly-Connected Edge List (DCEL).

remarks.para: This implementation follows the description of Doubly-Connected Edge Lists in the book "Computational Geometry", de Berg et al.
This class exposes one vertex of the mesh. Other mesh components can be found by navigating the DCEL data structures beginning at .

For convenience, component lists (, and ) are automatically generated when required. Whenever the mesh is modified (components are added or removed), the flag must be set. Then the component list are automatically recreated the next time they are accessed.

Handling Tags: The DCEL data structures (, and ) have "tags" (integer properties) which can be used to mark components when navigating or modifying the mesh. This tags can be used by different operations that act on the mesh.

member.summary: Cuts mesh with a plane.

remarks.para: The mesh is cut with the given plane. If any parts are in front of the plane, they are removed. Edges and faces that go through the plane are cut. The resulting mesh is closed with a new face in the cut plane.
If the whole mesh is in front of the plane, the whole mesh is removed ( is set to ). If the whole mesh is behind the plane, this method does nothing.

member.summary: Modifies a convex mesh by reducing the vertices and applying a skin width.
member.param: The width of the skin along the x, y and z directions.

remarks.para: Prerequisites: This operation uses of the vertices and it assumes that the mesh is valid, convex and closed. All faces must be triangles or convex polygons.

The number of vertices in the convex mesh is reduced to the given . If this operation has to remove vertices, the mesh grows to a bigger convex mesh. The method tries to remove only the vertices with the least influence.
All faces are extruded along the normal by the given skin width. The skin width causes the convex mesh to grow (positive skin width) or shrink (negative skin width). The result is again convex.

The angle limit in radians. Normals are only merged if the angle between the triangle normals is equal to or less than the angle limit. Set this value to -1 to disable the angle limit (all normals of one vertex are merged).
member.returns: If no angle limit is used (angle limit is -1), an array with one normal per vertex is returned. If an angle limit is used, an array with one normal per index is used.

This method computes vertex normals by averaging the triangle normals.
Angle limit: The can be used to keep sharp edges between triangles. If the angle limit is used, the returned array contains one entry per index (= 3 entries per triangle) because the normal of a vertex can have different direction for each neighbor triangle. If the angle limit is not used, the returned array contains one entry per vertex because the vertex normal of a single vertex is the same for all neighboring triangles.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Partitioning.AdaptiveAabbTree`1
member.summary: Builds a bounding volume tree using axis-aligned bounding boxes (AABBs), which adapts automatically when items are added, moved, or removed.
member.typeparam: The type of item in the spatial partition.

remarks.para:
The is based on
Thomas Larsson: "Adaptive Bounding Volume Hierarchies for Efficient Collision Queries", Ph D Thesis, Mlardalen University Press, January, 2009
Thomas Larsson, Tomas Akenine-Mller: "A dynamic bounding volume hierarchy for generalized collision detection", Computers & Graphics, Volume 30, Issue 3, p.451-460, June, 2006
The was designed to manage deformable objects efficiently. It should be used for s or s when the contained shapes or triangles are updated at runtime.

vs. : The and the are similar data structures. As a general rule, the should be used if
The entire spatial partition is invalidated regularly by calling .
The spatial partition is used to compute inter-object overlaps and intra-object overlaps (see ) are disabled.
Whereas the should be used if
Individual items are invalidated frequently by calling .
Inter-objects and/or intra-object overlaps (see ) are computed.
The should not be used as the collision detection broad-phase (see ). Whereas, a can be used as the collision detection broad-phase.
However, please note these are just general guidelines. You should always try different types and measure which one yields the best performance in your application.

Special handling of self-overlaps in : If is used to test an AABB tree against itself then overlaps of an item with itself are not returned; that means, each item A overlaps with itself but (A, A) is not returned. And if two different items overlap, only one overlap is returned, for example: If item A and item B overlap (A, B) or (B, A) is returned but not both.

member.summary: Gets or sets the threshold that determines when a bottom-up tree build method is used.
member.value: The threshold that determines when the tree is built using a bottom-up method. The default value is 128.

remarks.para: AABB trees can be built using top-down or bottom-up methods. Top-down methods are faster but less optimal. Bottom-up methods are slower but produce more balanced trees.
The uses a mixed approach: It starts with a top-down approach. When the number of nodes for an internal subtree is less than or equal to it uses a bottom-up method for the subtree.
Increasing produces a better tree but (re)building the tree takes more time. Decreasing decreases the build time but produces less optimal trees.
Changing does not change the tree structure immediately. It takes effect the next time the tree is rebuilt.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Partitioning.CompressedAabbTree.Node
member.summary: Represents a node of an .

remarks.para: The minimum and maximum of the AABB are stored as quantized 16-bit integer values.

The supports a stackless, non-recursive traversal of the tree. The tree is traversed in pre-order traversal order. The nodes are stored in the order as they are visited in the traversal: The left child follows the parent node. The right child follows after the left subtree. If a node is a leaf then the right sibling directly follows. The leaf nodes store the actual items of the AABB tree. Each non-leaf stores an 'escape offset'. This offset points to the node that follows in the traversal if we stop traversing a left subtree and continue with its right subtree. By using an escape offset we do not need to store the root of the right subtree on a stack (implicitly or explicitly).

The field is negative if the node is an internal node and the field contains an escape offset (escapeOffset = -node.EscapeOffsetOrItem). The value is positive if the node is a leaf and contains an item index.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Partitioning.DynamicAabbTree`1
member.summary: Represents a dynamic bounding volume tree using axis-aligned bounding boxes (AABBs).
member.typeparam: The type of item in the spatial partition.

remarks.para: The was inspired by the dynamic bounding volume tree (btDbvt) as implemented in the Bullet Continuous Collision Detection and Physics Library. (Original btDbvt implementation by Nathanael Presson.)
The was designed to manage deformable objects efficiently. It should be uses for s or s when the the contained shapes or triangles are updated at runtime.
It can also be used as a collision detection broad-phase (see ).

Incremental Optimization: When items in the AABB tree are added, removed or moved the AABB tree might become unbalanced and less optimal for collision detection. Therefore, the tries to optimize its tree structure over time. In each frame (time step) it performs a number of optimization passes. The amount of optimization per frame can be controlled by setting .

Motion Prediction: The dynamic AABB tree is further optimized for models/space where items are constantly moving. The automatically detects when items are moving. It adds a small margin (see ) to the AABB of these items to account for small random movements ("jittering") and it extends the AABB in the direction the items are moving (see ). This reduces the number of required tree updates per frame. However, the downside is that the AABB tree is more conservative (safe, but less accurate). It might return more overlaps ("false positives") than other types of spatial partitions.
Motion predication can be enabled by setting . The feature is disabled by default.

vs. : The and the are similar data structures. As a general rule, the should be used if
The entire spatial partition is invalidated regularly by calling .
The spatial partition is used to compute inter-object overlaps and intra-object overlaps (see ) are disabled.
Whereas the should be used if
Individual items are invalidated frequently by calling .
Items are added or removed frequently. (Inserting or removing individual items into/from a is fast.)
The should not be used as the collision detection broad-phase (see ). Whereas, a can be used as the collision detection broad-phase.
However, please note these are just general rules. You should always try different types and measure which one yields the best performance in your application.

Special handling of self-overlaps in : If is used to test an AABB tree against itself then overlaps of an item with itself are not returned. That means, each item A overlaps with itself, but (A, A) is not returned. And if two different items overlap, only one overlap is returned, for example: If item A and item B overlap (A, B) or (B, A) is returned, but not both.

member.summary: Represents a bounding volume tree using axis-aligned bounding boxes (AABBs).
member.typeparam: The type of item in the spatial partition.

remarks.para: partitions are good for partitioning static models or spaces where items are not changed at runtime or when the changes are small or local. For example, an is appropriate for managing large static triangle meshes efficiently. But they are not suitable for dynamic models or spaces where items are added/removed at runtime or when the large changes are applied to items.
Consider using the instead of the if items of type need to be stored. The reduced the memory requirements considerably.

Special handling of self-overlaps in : If is used to test an AABB tree against itself then overlaps of an item with itself are not returned; that means, each item A overlaps with itself but (A, A) is not returned. And if two different items overlap, only one overlap is returned, for example: If item A and item B overlap (A, B) or (B, A) is returned but not both.

member.summary: Gets or sets the threshold that determines when a bottom-up tree build method is used.

remarks.para: AABB trees can be built using top-down or bottom-up methods. Top-down methods are faster but less optimal. Bottom-up methods are slower but produce more balanced trees.
The uses a mixed approach: It starts with a top-down approach. When the number of nodes for an internal subtree is less than or equal to it uses a bottom-up method for the subtree.
Increasing produces a better tree but (re)building the tree takes more time. Decreasing decreases the build time but produces less optimal trees.
Changing does not change the tree structure immediately. It takes effect the next time the tree is rebuilt.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Partitioning.ISpatialPartition`1
member.summary: Efficiently manages items in a space or of a model using their spatial properties.
member.typeparam: The type of the items.

remarks.para: A spatial partition is a of items of a model or in a space. Spatial partitioning structures items according to their position and extents in space. This is usually used to manage the objects of a 3D model (using bounding box trees or other methods) or objects in a 3D space (using grids, octrees, etc.). Spatial partitions allow fast queries on the items. For example: "Give me all items that touch a given axis aligned bounding box." Or: "Give me all pairs of touching items."
The items in the spatial partitions (see type parameter ) can be of any kind: integer values that define triangle indices of a triangle mesh, or in a space, ...

Creating Spatial Partitions: A is a , so items can be added and removed. The internal structure will be built when is called. When items move or change their shape, the spatial partition must be informed using (for a single item) or (if more or all items have changed). Then must be called to rebuild the internal structure.

Calling Add/Remove/Invalidate methods are fast operations. The internal work is done when is called. If is not called by the owner of the spatial partition, then it will be automatically called when (or one of its overloads) is called.

Querying Spatial Partitions: A has several GetOverlaps methods that allow to get all the items that touch a specific item or region. These queries are more efficient than enumerating and testing all contained items manually. Some queries return s which describe pairs of touching objects.

Spatial partitions use approximate representations of the managed items - usually bounding volumes instead of the actual geometry. For example, when using a items are represented using their axis-aligned bounding box (AABB). The GetOverlaps methods only test the bounding volumes against each other to check for potential intersections. When a GetOverlaps method returns an item or an item pair, it is not guaranteed that the items are actually touching - for returned items the spatial partition computed that it is very likely that they are touching. For example: When managing triangles with the help of an the method returns all triangles where the bounding boxes overlap. Overlapping bounding volumes do not guarantee that the contained items are actually intersecting - the triangles could still be separated.
A spatial partition does not replace a detailed collision detection. It only helps to efficiently sort out items that do not intersect.

AABB Computation of Items: When creating an instance of an a callback that computes the for a given item must be specified. The spatial partition does not know how to compute the positions and extents of the items. The delegate is used to compute an s for each item. The computed is used to define the spatial properties of an item. For a single item the method must always return the same . If the AABB of an item has changed (e.g. the item has moved or changed shape), must be called.

Self Overlaps: A self-overlap is an overlap of two items where both items are contained in the spatial partition. Self-overlaps are only computed if is set. Self-overlaps can be queried using . Overlaps of a single item with itself are never returned.

Filtering: Per default, no filter is set and GetOverlaps methods return all found overlaps. A can be set. Then, whenever a pair of items is tested the overlap will only be accepted if returns . The filter is not used if an item is tested against an or a .

Rebuild versus Refit: The spatial partitioning is performed when is called. The spatial partition will build a new internal structure if many or all items are new or were invalidated (see ). If only a few items were changed, the spatial partition will perform a faster "refit" operation that changes only the relevant parts of the internal structure. Depending on the type of spatial partitioning, refit operations can lead to less optimal internal structures. The method has a forceRebuild parameter with which a complete rebuild can be demanded.

Cloning: Spatial partitions are cloneable. Cloning creates a deep copy of the spatial partition. All properties and internal data structures are duplicated. However, the items contained in the spatial partitions are not copied. The clone will be an empty spatial partition that can be used independently from the original spatial partitions.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Partitioning.ISupportClosestPointQueries`1
member.summary: Indicates that an object (normally a ) has special support for closest-point queries.
member.typeparam: The type of the queried items.

remarks.para: Given a collection of items, the goal is to find the item that is closest to a given item or volume. Without further information the closest-point on each item in the collection has to be computed, and the item with the smallest closest-point distance is the winner. Some s have an internal structure that can speed up the search.

The methods in this interface find the items that are good candidates to be closest to the given volume (axis-aligned bounding box or another partition). A callback method is called with each candidate item. The callback must compute the closest-point on the item and return the squared closest-point distance. The returned value helps the spatial partition to filter out bad candidates.

The callback method must return 0 if the candidate item is touching/penetrating the other item. -1 can be returned if the search for more candidates should be aborted. The callback can return positive infinity if it cannot compute a squared closest point distance.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Partitioning.ISupportFrustumCulling`1
member.summary: Indicates that an object (normally a ) has special support for frustum culling.
member.typeparam: The type of the queried items.

remarks.para: It is recommended to use a type of that implements this interface in the of a collision domain, if the collision domain is used for frustum culling.

In general frustum culling can be done by adding a collision object for the viewing frustum (usually a shape) to a collision domain. The objects inside the viewing frustum can then be queried by calling . This approach is acceptable for small scenes, but it does not perform well in large, complex scenes.

A viewing frustum of a camera has certain characteristics that reduce performance of a collision domain: The viewing frustum is usually extremely large and can cover entire scenes. The camera usually moves every frame. Therefore, when the object is added to a collision domain a large number of contact sets is created and updated every frame.

Luckily frustum culling does not need to be exact: In most cases it is sufficient to only check the axis-aligned bounding boxes (AABBs) of the scene objects against the viewing frustum. This can be done manually by calling against the of a collision domain and skip the narrow phase of the collision detection. In this case the viewing frustum does not need to be added to the collision domain!

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Pose
member.summary: A pose defines the position and orientation of a shape in world space (or the parent coordinate space).

remarks.para: This type represents an affine transformation consisting only of a rotation followed by a translation - no scaling. This transformation transforms coordinates from local space to world space (or a parent space). Every has a which defines position and orientation of the figure in the parent's space which is usually the world space.

For hierarchical objects, like s, a pose defines the relationship of a local coordinates system to a parent coordinate system. For example: The children of a are of type . So each child of a has a which defines the position and orientation of the child in the local space of the . The local space of the is the parent space of the child.

Important: When creating a new do not use Pose p = new Pose(); instead use Pose p = Pose.Identity. The constructor new Pose() initializes the orientation quaternion elements with 0 and thus is not a valid transformation.
Notes: The name "pose" comes from the definition: "to pose = to put or set in place".

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Shapes.CompositeShape
member.summary: Represents a shape consisting of several other geometric objects.

remarks.para: This shape is a collection of geometric objects (see ). Each child has a , and a (= position and orientation). All children are defined in the local space of the composite shape. That means that the defines the position and orientation of each child relative to the parent composite shape. The resulting composite shape can be concave.
Other names for this type of shape: Complex, Compound, Group, ...

Spatial Partitioning: A spatial partitioning method (see can be used to improve runtime performance if this composite shape consists of a lot of children. A spatial partition improves the collision detection speed at the cost of additional memory. If is , no spatial partitioning method is used (which is the default). If a spatial partitioning scheme should be used, the property must be set to an instance of . The items in the spatial partition will be the indices of the of this composite shape. The composite shape will automatically fill and update the spatial partition. Following example shows how a complex composite shape can be improved by using an AABB tree:
myCompositeShape.Partition = new AabbTree<int>();
Shape Features: If a is involved in a , the shape feature property ( and ) contains the index of the child that caused the .
Cloning: If a is cloned, all and the spatial partition (if any is in use) will be cloned (deep copy).

remarks.para: A height field is defined by a 1-dimensional array () which contains x height values. This array is triangulated. Each array element defines a triangle vertex. The height samples are addressed like this:
The height field is placed in the local x/z plane where the up direction is the positive y-axis. The top-left height field corner (Samples[0]) is positioned at x = and z = .
The height field is stretched to fill a rectangle x .

Holes in the height field can be created by setting a height value in the to . All triangles touching the "hole" vertex will be removed. This also means that the shape of the hole depends on the current tessellation pattern. If all elements in the are , then the behavior of the height field is undefined.

Limitations of holes and collision detection: Please note that computation of , might not work as expected if an object moves through a hole and under the height field. Also computation of contacts might not work as expected on the border triangles near the hole. For good collision detection results it is recommended to avoid closest points queries for objects under the height field and to always surround a hole with other collision objects. For instance if there is a cave in a game terrain, make the hole larger than the cave entrance and surround it with additional rock meshes.

Shape Features: If a is involved in a the shape feature property ( or ) contains the index of the triangle that creates the : Each cell consists of two triangles. The first cell contains the triangles 0 and 1. The next cell in positive x direction contains the triangles 2 and 3. And so on. To compute an index all cells of a row in positive x direction are enumerated then the next x-row is enumerated and so on.

para.c: HeightField { Samples=float[200], OriginX=3000, OriginY =4000, WidthX=100, WidthZ=200 }

example.para: This creates a height field in the x/z plane. The field is 100 units wide in the x-axis and 200 units wide in the z-axis. The array element [0] defines the height field height at x = 3000, z = 4000. The array element [199] defines the height field height at x = 3100, z = 4200
The must contain at least 2 x 2 elements.
For best performance, s that have a shape should use only 90 degree rotations in their . The local x/z plane of the height field should be normal to a world space axis plane.

For a height field the collision behavior is only defined in the x/z range of the height field. Beyond the height field limits the collision behavior is undefined. For example, if a box is left of the height field and moves sideways into the height field, the closest-point and contact information might not be intuitive and such cases should be avoided.

remarks.para: This 1-dimensional array contains the height samples of the rectangular height field. The array must contain at least NumberOfSamplesX * NumberSamplesZ elements. The elements are addressed like this: height(indexX, indexZ) = Samples[indexZ * NumberOfSamplesX + indexX].

member.summary: Represents a perspective view volume (frustum).

remarks.para: A perspective view volume is a frustum. A frustum is a portion of a pyramid that lies between two cutting planes.

The class is designed to model the view volume of a perspective camera: The observer is looking from the origin along the negative z-axis. member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Shapes.Plane
member.summary: Defines a plane.

remarks.para: This is a lightweight structure. To define a plane shape for use .

A plane can be described by a plane equation: a * x + b * y + c * z = d, where (x, y, z) is a point on the plane and (a, b, c) is the vector. d is the "plane constant", which is equal to the distance from the origin if the normal is normalized.
Two s are considered as equal if and are equal.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Geometry.Shapes.Plane.DistanceFromOrigin

remarks.para: This value is the plane constant d from the plane equation a * x + b * y + c * z = d. If the is normalized, then this value is the distance from the plane point nearest to the origin projected onto the normal vector. This distance can be negative to signify a negative plane offset.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Shapes.RayShape
member.summary: Represents a ray, which can be used for ray casting.

remarks.para: This class can be used if an with a ray shape is needed. Use the structure instead if you need a lightweight representation of a ray (avoids allocating memory on the heap).
In contrast to a real ray, a object has a finite length! Infinite rays should not be used because finite rays are faster and produce less numerical problems.

Important: Do not put rays into composite shapes (for example ). If a composite shape collides with another object, all contacts of this object pair are merged into a single . Thus, ray hits of child rays of the composite shape are "merged" with normal contacts of other child shapes; the result is undefined.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Shapes.Shape
member.summary: Defines the volume of an .

remarks.para: A defines the space that is occupied by an object. is the common base class of all types of shapes in DigitalRune Geometry.

Shapes are defined in the local coordinate system of the owning object (also known as local space, object space or body space). Shapes are abstracted from other properties such as color, material, or even position and orientation. Most shapes contain only properties that define their dimensions ("width", "height", "radius", etc.). For example, a consists only of a radius that defines the size of the sphere. The sphere is centered in the local coordinate system.
However, some shapes like the , the or the , are defined using position and orientation vectors ("Vertex0", "Origin", "Direction", etc.). Thus, they can be also positioned in local coordinate space.
An is used to position an object in the world coordinate space. An consists of a , a and a (= position and orientation).
Cloning: Shapes are cloneable. The method creates a deep copy of the shape - except when documented otherwise (see description of derived classes).

member.summary: Gets the volume of this shape.

The iteration limit. Must be greater than or equal to 0. For most cases a small value like 4 is appropriate.
member.returns: The volume of this shape.

remarks.para: If the volume can be computed with an exact formula, then the exact volume is returned. But for some shapes an approximate volume is computed. For approximated volumes defines the desired relative error and if the volume is computed by an iterative algorithm, no more than iterations are performed. If the is reached first, the returned mesh will have a higher relative error.

Currently, is proportional to the error of the approximated volume. But it is not guaranteed that the relative error between the approximated volume and the exact volume is less than . It is only guaranteed that a smaller value leads to a more accurate approximation.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Geometry.Shapes.TriangleMeshShape
member.summary: Represents a shape defined by an .

remarks.para: One-sided and two-sided meshes: Per default, the collision detection treats the triangle mesh as one-sided ( is ); that means, only the front side of a triangle is solid. If the collision detection is used in a physics simulation, then objects can pass through the back side of a triangle. can be set to to treat the mesh as two-sided (double-sided).

Meshes are hollow: Further, meshes are not treated as solid volumes. For example if a triangle mesh represents a sphere and another object is inside the sphere but does not touch any triangles, then no collision is reported.

Spatial Partitioning: A spatial partitioning method (see can be used to improve runtime performance if the consists of a lot of triangles. A spatial partition improves the collision detection speed at the cost of additional memory. If is , no spatial partitioning method is used (which is the default). If a spatial partitioning scheme should be used, the property must be set to a instance. The items in the spatial partition will be the indices of the mesh triangles. The triangle mesh shape will automatically fill and update the spatial partition. Following example shows how a complex triangle mesh shape can be improved by using an AABB tree:
myTriangleMeshShape.Partition = new AabbTree<int>();
Shape Features: If a is involved in a the shape feature property ( and ) contains the index of the triangle that causes the .
Cloning: A can be cloned. The clone will reference the same (shallow copy)! If a is in use, the spatial partition will be cloned.
